articles.headline: Voting Machines Giving Florida New Headache
articles.snippet: Touch screens bought after 2000 have now been deemed failures and must be replaced with optical-scan machines.
articles.abstract: Touch screens bought after 2000 have now been deemed failures and must be replaced with optical-scan machines.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Oct. 12 — It used to be that everyone wanted a Florida voting machine.

articles.headline: New Evidence That Blackwater Guards Took No Fire
articles.snippet: Fresh accounts of a shooting in Baghdad last month cast further doubt on guards’ statements that they were responding to insurgents.
articles.abstract: Fresh accounts of a shooting in Baghdad last month cast further doubt on guards’ statements that they were responding to insurgents.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by James Glanz, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and  Michael Kamber and written by Mr. Glanz.

articles.headline: As Logging Fades, Rich Carve Up Open Land in West
articles.snippet: With the timber industry in decline, some new investors are snapping up open spaces to be private playgrounds.
articles.abstract: With the timber industry in decline, some new investors are snapping up open spaces to be private playgrounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITEFISH, Mont. — William P. Foley II pointed to the mountain. Owns it, mostly. A timber company began logging in view of his front yard a few years back. He thought they were cutting too much, so he bought the land.

articles.headline: No Flinching From Recalls as China’s Exports Soar
articles.snippet: Despite growing scrutiny of the quality and safety of Chinese goods, China’s exports are up 27 percent so far this year.
articles.abstract: Despite growing scrutiny of the quality and safety of Chinese goods, China’s exports are up 27 percent so far this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, Oct. 12 — Despite a wave of high-profile recalls, and growing scrutiny of the quality and safety of Chinese goods, China’s export boom continues, according to newly released statistics from both independent analysts and the government in Beijing.

articles.headline: What if C.E.O. Pay Is Fair?
articles.snippet: Executive pay practices may have helped drive strong corporate performance, but what about the moral element?
articles.abstract: Executive pay practices may have helped drive strong corporate performance, but what about the moral element?
articles.lead_paragraph: “I really don’t want to answer that question,” said Ira T. Kay, flashing me some combination of half-grin and half-grimace. “I have clients.”

articles.headline: The Man Who Won as Others Lost
articles.snippet: Paul Tudor Jones II, one of Wall Street’s most fabled financial speculators, predicted the 1987 market crash but today is keeping quiet about the market.
articles.abstract: Paul Tudor Jones II, one of Wall Street’s most fabled financial speculators, predicted the 1987 market crash but today is keeping quiet about the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul Tudor Jones II leans back in his chair and grins. The stock market is going to crash, and he knows it. “There will be some type of a decline, without a question, in the next 10, 20 months,” he says in his rich Memphis drawl. “And it will be earth-shaking; it will be saber-rattling.”

articles.headline: As Its Stock Tops $600, Google Faces Growing Risks
articles.snippet: While Google’s stock climbs ever higher, threats to its dominance of the industry are mounting as well.
articles.abstract: While Google’s stock climbs ever higher, threats to its dominance of the industry are mounting as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can anything stop the ascent of Google’s stock?

articles.headline: Rate Chasers Are Online and Moving Cash Quickly
articles.snippet: Day trading has morphed into rate chasing. The chasers search for the best rates at credit unions and banks, moving cash swiftly from one account to another.
articles.abstract: Day trading has morphed into rate chasing. The chasers search for the best rates at credit unions and banks, moving cash swiftly from one account to another.
articles.lead_paragraph: They’re a latter-day version of day traders. Rate chasers, they call themselves: savers who hunt for the best interest rates at banks and credit unions and quickly move their cash from one account to another.

articles.headline: I.R.S. Looks at Mortgage Securities
articles.snippet: The I.R.S. is examining the use of arcane but powerful investment entities known as real estate mortgage investment conduits to see if participants are reaping illegal tax benefits.
articles.abstract: The I.R.S. is examining the use of arcane but powerful investment entities known as real estate mortgage investment conduits to see if participants are reaping illegal tax benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service is checking out dozens of participants in a financial arrangement to see if they are reaping illegal tax benefits by underreporting income on mortgage-backed securities, which make up the bulk of the multitrillion-dollar market for asset-backed securities.

articles.headline: Gore Shares Peace Prize for Climate Change Work
articles.snippet: The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to Al Gore and to a United Nations panel for their work on global warming.
articles.abstract: The Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to Al Gore and to a United Nations panel for their work on global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO, Oct. 12 — Former Vice President Al Gore, who emerged from his loss in the muddled 2000 presidential election to devote himself to his passion as an environmental crusader, was awarded the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, sharing it with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a United Nations network of scientists.
articles.byline: By Walter Gibbs and Sarah Lyall

articles.headline: At an Army School for Officers, Blunt Talk About Iraq
articles.snippet: Fort Leavenworth, Kan., the intellectual center of the U.S. Army, has become a front line in the military’s soul-searching over Iraq.
articles.abstract: Fort Leavenworth, Kan., the intellectual center of the U.S. Army, has become a front line in the military’s soul-searching over Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan. — Here at the intellectual center of the United States Army, two elite officers were deep in debate at lunch on a recent day over who bore more responsibility for mistakes in Iraq — the former defense secretary, Donald H. Rumsfeld, or the generals who acquiesced to him.

articles.headline: Clinton-Obama Quandary for Many Black Women
articles.snippet: In interviews, black women in South Carolina expressed ambivalence over the two presidential candidates.
articles.abstract: In interviews, black women in South Carolina expressed ambivalence over the two presidential candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: LORIS, S.C. — In the beauty parlors that are among the social hubs for black women in the Carolinas, loyalties are being tested as voters here contemplate the first Democratic primary in the South.

articles.headline: Portable Halls of Justice Are Rising in Guantánamo
articles.snippet: In the long-running limbo that is Guantánamo, a portable complex to try detainees may be the perfect architecture.
articles.abstract: In the long-running limbo that is Guantánamo, a portable complex to try detainees may be the perfect architecture.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — If everything goes according to plan, trials of detainees could begin here soon in a court building now under construction next to an unused runway set against the glittering sea.

articles.headline: The New Advertising Outlet: Your Life
articles.snippet: Huge amounts of advertising money are flowing out of the traditional media and into alternatives — even as ad budgets in general are growing.
articles.abstract: Huge amounts of advertising money are flowing out of the traditional media and into alternatives — even as ad budgets in general are growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEVE SAENZ used to run a 10K race in 36 minutes. But last spring — 20 years, 2 children and 50 pounds later — he found himself seriously out of shape. A new Web site from Nike, he says, has brought him back on track.

articles.headline: In China, a Lake’s Champion Imperils Himself
articles.snippet: Lake Tai, the center of China’s ancient “land of fish and rice,” succumbed this year to floods of man-made waste. By then, the activist who had been trying to save the lake was in jail.
articles.abstract: Lake Tai, the center of China’s ancient “land of fish and rice,” succumbed this year to floods of man-made waste. By then, the activist who had been trying to save the lake was in jail.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHOUTIE, China — Lake Tai, the center of China’s ancient “land of fish and rice,” succumbed this year to floods of industrial and agricultural waste.

articles.headline: The Owners Who Can’t Hire or Fire
articles.snippet: Why is it so hard for investors to have a say?
articles.abstract: Why is it so hard for investors to have a say?
articles.lead_paragraph: INVESTORS may have hoped that the Securities and Exchange Commission would do the right thing and allow them a much more active role in governance matters at their companies. Ownership usually brings certain rights, after all.

articles.headline: Some States Consider Leasing Their Lotteries
articles.snippet: With billions to gain, government officials in at least a dozen states are considering lottery privatizations.
articles.abstract: With billions to gain, government officials in at least a dozen states are considering lottery privatizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS chief operating officer of the California Department of Finance, Fred Klass gets pitches from Wall Street bankers as often as the rest of us might get cold calls from telemarketers or insurance agents. But when Kathleen Brown of Goldman Sachs came to his office earlier this year and suggested privatizing the state lottery, Mr. Klass listened closely.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: A Little Mexican Cafe, Built on Persistence
articles.snippet: When banks said no to a $20,000 loan, a nonprofit said yes.
articles.abstract: When banks said no to a $20,000 loan, a nonprofit said yes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Gladys and Jose Remache arrived in the United States from the Mexican state of Puebla 16 years ago, they did what many poor immigrants have traditionally done: obtained jobs on the bottom rungs of the economy.

articles.headline: With Tight Grip on Ballot, Putin Is Forcing Foes Out
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin is poised to extinguish the last embers of opposition in Russia’s Parliament.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin is poised to extinguish the last embers of opposition in Russia’s Parliament.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Oct. 13 — Balloting for Parliament will be held across Russia in December, and this much is already clear: Vladimir A. Ryzhkov, who was first elected in the turbulent yet hopeful days after the Soviet Union’s fall and then blossomed into a fervent advocate for democracy, will lose.

articles.headline: A Golf Course Where Water Is No Hazard
articles.snippet: Afghanistan’s only golf course is the result of one man’s dreamy vision nudged ever closer to a rugged reality.
articles.abstract: Afghanistan’s only golf course is the result of one man’s dreamy vision nudged ever closer to a rugged reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: QARGHA, Afghanistan — Gazing down the valley here on Kabul’s western outskirts, Mohammad Afzal Abdul does not see the sun-blasted sweep of scrubland and rocks apparent to everyone else.

articles.headline: Group Plans to Provide Investigative Journalism
articles.snippet: Pro Publica hopes to fill in recent cutbacks in investigative reporting by giving away its work to newspapers and magazines where it will make the strongest impression.
articles.abstract: Pro Publica hopes to fill in recent cutbacks in investigative reporting by giving away its work to newspapers and magazines where it will make the strongest impression.
articles.lead_paragraph: As struggling newspapers across the country cut back on investigative reporting, a new kind of journalism venture is hoping to fill the gap.

articles.headline: An Internet Jihad Aims at U.S. Viewers
articles.snippet: A growing constellation of apparently independent operators is broadcasting the message of Al Qaeda and other groups, translated into English and aimed for a Western audience online.
articles.abstract: A growing constellation of apparently independent operators is broadcasting the message of Al Qaeda and other groups, translated into English and aimed for a Western audience online.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Osama bin Laden issued his videotaped message to the American people last month, a young jihad enthusiast went online to help spread the word.
articles.byline: By Michael Moss and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: A Shake-Up at Citigroup May Follow Earlier One
articles.snippet: Recent problems have raised new doubts about Charles O. Prince III’s ability to manage Citigroup, despite strong support from the company’s directors and biggest shareholder.
articles.abstract: Recent problems have raised new doubts about Charles O. Prince III’s ability to manage Citigroup, despite strong support from the company’s directors and biggest shareholder.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Citigroup’s chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, shook up the leadership and structure of the investment banking unit last week, the move signaled a willingness to take dramatic action.

articles.headline: Can Fox Win Its Frontal Assault Against CNBC?
articles.snippet: Fox Business Network has made no secret that it intends to do in the realm of business news exactly what the Fox News Channel did in general news: conquer.
articles.abstract: Fox Business Network has made no secret that it intends to do in the realm of business news exactly what the Fox News Channel did in general news: conquer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The team leading the Fox Business Network into battle with CNBC, the entrenched leader in cable business news, has made no secret that it intends to do in the realm of business news exactly what the Fox News Channel did in general news. As in: conquer.

articles.headline: P.&G., the Pioneer of Mixing Soap and Drama, Adds a Web Installment
articles.snippet: The consumer products giant has created “Crescent Heights,” a new online soap opera that aims to reach young viewers where they watch most — their PCs and cellphones.
articles.abstract: The consumer products giant has created “Crescent Heights,” a new online soap opera that aims to reach young viewers where they watch most — their PCs and cellphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can young Ashley find success and happiness in the big city? Will the dashing Eric win her heart? Can she make consumers buy more Tide detergent?

articles.headline: Weinsteins: More Misses Than Hits
articles.snippet: Now that the Weinsteins have what they want — independence — they can’t seem to achieve what they keenly desire — success on their own terms.
articles.abstract: Now that the Weinsteins have what they want — independence — they can’t seem to achieve what they keenly desire — success on their own terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you asked almost anybody in the movie industry to wager on how Harvey Weinstein and his brother, Bob, would fare after they left Disney in 2005 and started their own company, the smart money would have bet on this: the Weinstein brothers, who helped bring the world “Good Will Hunting,” “Pulp Fiction,” “The English Patient” and “Shakespeare in Love,” would still make splashy movies and be a big factor at the Oscars, but they would spend like pirates and their backers at Goldman Sachs would regret allowing them to get their hands on a billion dollars.

articles.headline: Patients Warned as Maker Halts Sale of Heart Implant Part
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest maker of implanted heart devices said a component in its most recent defibrillator has malfunctioned in hundreds of patients and may have contributed to five deaths.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest maker of implanted heart devices said a component in its most recent defibrillator has malfunctioned in hundreds of patients and may have contributed to five deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s largest maker of implanted heart devices, Medtronic, said yesterday that it was urging doctors to stop using a crucial component in its most recent defibrillator models because it was prone to a defect that has caused malfunctions in hundreds of patients and may have contributed to five deaths.

articles.headline: Giuliani Sells New York as the Town He Tamed
articles.snippet: As a candidate for president, Rudolph W. Giuliani is at once running against New York City and embracing it.
articles.abstract: As a candidate for president, Rudolph W. Giuliani is at once running against New York City and embracing it.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 13 — It was a depressed and devastated place: a city shoulder-to-shoulder with welfare recipients, free-spending city officials and greedy lawyers. New York was, in the telling of Rudolph W. Giuliani, a haven of high taxes and high crime, crumbling buildings and filthy streets. It was governed by liberals and dominated by Democratic voters who did not agree with the ideas of Mr. Giuliani but who nonetheless twice elected him mayor.
